From Mendelian Research and Models to the Present: Advances, Ambiguities and Persisting Questions
3. From Mendelian Research and Models to the Present: Advances, Ambiguities and Persisting Questions

The conservatism expressed in Johannsen (1911) about identifying the
material basis of genes, as the nature of the germ cells shared by a
genotype, was not so evident among the Mendelian researchers who
quickly came to adopt the new terms gene, genotype, and phenotype
during that decade. The focus moved beyond refuting what Johannsen
called the “transmission-conception” of heredity and
towards heredity as transmission in the new sense of genes going from
parents to the germ cells of offspring
 (Figure 3).
 Research in laboratory genetics and agricultural breeding extended
Mendelian methods productively, but it also allowed some of the
conceptual and methodological problems of Johannsen introduced in
 section 2
 to persist and ramify.
